What is the current state of social tokens in the decentralized blockchain world?

The current state of social tokens is limited and inaccessible to many creators. Leading social token platforms, Roll and Rally, require a detailed application process and approval before creators can issue their own social tokens. This process can be time-consuming and favors creators with existing large communities and transaction activity. Additionally, creators who want to issue social tokens independently face a complex and limiting process that requires significant development expertise.

interested in creating a social token is met with an odd reality in the “decentralized” blockchain world. Both Roll and Rally, the social token leaders, require creators to go through a detailed application process, and then wait for approval. The Rally website says they’re looking for: “1) Evidence of a significant community size, … 2) Evidence of current transaction activity within your community … 3) Evidence that you have strongly considered the role that a social token economy would play in your ongoing projects.” Creators then wait for a review before being approved. Roll’s business model is to take a portion of the creator’s token for themselves. Rally’s is a little more sophisticated, attempting to have value created in their own token and sidechain in the process.
This makes sense for Roll and Rally because there is significant engineering and other work required to get the contracts up and running that define the social token and provide it liquidity. Creators who want to “do it themselves” are met with an arduous and limiting process — essentially, they need to be decent developers to get their tokens going. And to do all that for a one-dimensional token that can only be sent back and forth or placed in an AMM seems to be an unattractive proposition.
The result is that social tokens have yet to fulfill their promise. There’s no easy way for just anyone to do permissionless experiments at little cost, and little risk. And, when they do experiment, there is only the hope that by tying real world activities to their token, they might generate some value there, at least while they continue to offer those activities. This purported value is difficult to measure, and tough to capture, and exhausting to maintain. So there’s no real innovation and no “long tail” that allows unexpected modes of organization and value creation to emerge.

Why do social token platforms like Roll and Rally have strict requirements for creators?

Roll and Rally have strict requirements for creators because they need to invest significant engineering and development resources to set up and maintain the contracts that define and provide liquidity to social tokens. In return, they take a portion of the creator's token (Roll) or attempt to create value in their own token and sidechain (Rally).

What are the limitations of current social token platforms for creators?

Current social token platforms are limited in that they require creators to have significant development expertise, a large existing community, and transaction activity. They also offer limited flexibility and innovation, as creators are tied to the platform's rules and requirements. This makes it difficult for creators to experiment with new ideas and modes of organization and value creation.

What is missing in the current social token landscape?

What is missing in the current social token landscape is an easy, permissionless, and low-cost way for creators to experiment with social tokens without needing extensive development expertise. This lack of accessibility and flexibility limits innovation and prevents the emergence of new and unexpected modes of organization and value creation.
